snippet: As North Koreans watched the unusual spectacle of Jang Song-thaek’s arrest on television, Chinese leaders were concerned about the loss of one of their major links to the leadership of the North.
abstract: China's leaders are surprised and unnerved by public ouster of North Korea's Jang Song-thaek, country's No. 2 figure and revered uncle and mentor of paramount leader Kim Jong-un; as North's longtime protector and economic lifeline, China had built good relationship with Jang and any shift by China concerning North Korea has potential to significantly alter political equilibrium in Asia.

byline.original: By JANE PERLEZ and CHOE SANG-HUN
byline.contributor: Jane Perlez reported from Beijing, and Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea. Bree Feng contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: As North Koreans watched the unusual spectacle of Jang Song-thaek’s arrest on television, Chinese leaders were concerned about the loss of one of their major links to the leadership of the North.

headline.main: Public Ouster in North Korea Unsettles China
headline.print_headline: Public Ouster In North Korea Unsettles China
